description: From Middle English schore, from Old English *sċora (attested as sċor- in placenames), from Proto-Germanic *skurô (“rugged rock, cliff, high rocky shore”). Possibly related to Old English sċieran (“to cut”), which survives today as English shear.

Cognate with Middle Dutch scorre (“land washed by the sea”), Middle Low German schor (“shore, coast, headland”), Middle High German schorre ("rocky crag, high rocky shore"; > German Schorre,  Schorren (“towering rock, crag”)), and Limburgish sjaor (“riverbank”). Maybe connected with Norwegian Bokmål skjær.

entries.meaning: Land adjoining a non-flowing body of water, such as an ocean, lake or pond.
examples: lake shore;  bay shore;  gulf shore;  island shore;  mainland shore;  river shore;  estuary shore;  pond shore;  sandy shore;  rocky shore

entries.meaning: (from the perspective of one on a body of water) Land, usually near a port.
examples: The seamen were serving on shore instead of in ships.
The passengers signed up for shore tours.

verbs.description: shore (third-person singular simple present shores, present participle shoring, simple past and past participle shored)

description: From Late Middle English shore (“a prop, a support”) [and other forms], from Middle Dutch schore, schare (“a prop, a stay”) (modern Dutch schoor), and Middle Low German schōre, schāre (“a prop, a stay; barrier; stockade”) (compare Old Norse skorða (“a prop, a stay”) (Norwegian skor, skorda)); further etymology unknown.

entries.meaning: A prop or strut supporting some structure or weight above it.
examples: The shores stayed upright during the earthquake.

description: From Late Middle English shoren (“to prop, to support”) [and other forms], from Middle English shore (“a prop, a support”) (see etymology 2) + -en (suffix forming the infinitive form of verbs); compare Middle Dutch schooren (“to prop up, support”) and Middle Low German schore (“to shovel; to sweep”).

verbs.description: shore (third-person singular simple present shores, present participle shoring, simple past and past participle shored) (transitive)

entries.meaning: Not followed by up: to provide (something) with support.
Usually followed by up: to reinforce (something at risk of failure).
examples: My family shored me up after I failed the GED.
The workers were shoring up the dock after part of it fell into the water.

description: Perhaps a variant of score or sure, equivalent to assure.

verbs.description: shore (third-person singular simple present shores, present participle shoring, simple past and past participle shored) (transitive, Scotland, archaic)

adverbs.description: shore (comparative more shore, superlative most shore)
